A Dense Initialization for Limited-Memory Quasi-Newton Methods

Johannes Brust jbrust@ucmerced.edu Applied Mathematics, University of California, Merced, Merced, CA 95343 ,Â  Oleg Burdakov oleg.burdakov@liu.se Department of Mathematics, LinkÃ¶ping University, SE-581 83 LinkÃ¶ping, Sweden ,Â  Jennifer B. Erway erwayjb@wfu.edu Department of Mathematics, Wake Forest University, Winston-Salem, NC 27109 Â andÂ  Roummel F. Marcia rmarcia@ucmerced.edu Applied Mathematics, University of California, Merced, Merced, CA 95343
Abstract.

We consider a family of dense initializations for limited-memory quasi-Newton methods. The proposed initialization exploits an eigendecomposition-based separation of the full space into two complementary subspaces, assigning a different initialization parameter to each subspace. This family of dense initializations is proposed in the context of a limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) trust-region method that makes use of a shape-changing norm to define each subproblem. As with L-BFGS methods that traditionally use diagonal initialization, the dense initialization and the sequence of generated quasi-Newton matrices are never explicitly formed. Numerical experiments on the CUTEst test set suggest that this initialization together with the shape-changing trust-region method outperforms other L-BFGS methods for solving general nonconvex unconstrained optimization problems. While this dense initialization is proposed in the context of a special trust-region method, it has broad applications for more general quasi-Newton trust-region and line search methods. In fact, this initialization is suitable for use with any quasi-Newton update that admits a compact representation and, in particular, any member of the Broyden class of updates.

Key words and phrases:
Large-scale nonlinear optimization, limited-memory quasi-Newton methods, trust-region methods, quasi-Newton matrices, shape-changing norm

R.Â F. Marcia is supported in part by National Science Foundation grants CMMI-1333326 and IIS-1741490

1. Introduction

In this paper we propose a new dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods to solve problems of the form

Â minimizeÂ xâˆˆâ„œnâ€‹fâ€‹(x),ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘›Â minimizeÂ ğ‘“ğ‘¥\underset{x\in\Re^{n}}{\text{ minimize }}f(x),

where f:â„œnâ†’â„œ:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ‘›f:\Re^{n}\rightarrow\Re is at least a continuously differentiable function, which is not necessarily convex. The dense initialization matrix is designed to be updated each time a new quasi-Newton pair is computed (i.e., as often as once an iteration); however, in order to retain the efficiency of limited-memory quasi-Newton methods, the dense initialization matrix and the generated sequence of quasi-Newton matrices are not explicitly formed. This proposed initialization makes use of a partial eigendecomposition of these matrices for separating â„œnsuperscriptğ‘›\Re^{n} into two orthogonal subspaces â€“ one for which there is approximate curvature information and the other for which there is no reliable curvature information. This initialization has broad applications for general quasi-Newton trust-region and line search methods. In fact, this work can be applied to any quasi-Newton method that uses an update with a compact representation, which includes any member of the Broyden class of updates. For this paper, we explore its use in one specific algorithm; in particular we consider a limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) trust-region method where each subproblem is defined using a shape-changing normÂ [3]. The reason for this choice is that the dense initialization is naturally well-suited for solving L-BFGS trust-region subproblems defined by this norm. Numerical results on the CUTEst test set suggest that the dense initialization outperforms other L-BFGS methods.

The BFGS update is the most widely-used quasi-Newton update for large-scale optimization; it is defined by the recursion formula

Bk+1=Bkâˆ’1skTâ€‹Bkâ€‹skâ€‹Bkâ€‹skâ€‹skTâ€‹Bk+1skTâ€‹ykâ€‹ykâ€‹ykT,subscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğµğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜subscriptğµğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘˜B_{k+1}=B_{k}-\frac{1}{s^{T}_{k}B_{k}s_{k}}B_{k}s_{k}s_{k}^{T}B_{k}+\frac{1}{s^{T}_{k}y_{k}}y_{k}y^{T}_{k}, (1)

where

and B0âˆˆâ„œnÃ—nsubscriptğµ0superscriptğ‘›ğ‘›B_{0}\in\Re^{n\times n} is a suitably-chosen initial matrix. This rank-two update to Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} preserves positive definiteness when skTâ€‹yk>0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜0s^{T}_{k}y_{k}>0.

L-BFGS is a limited-memory variant of BFGS that only stores a predetermined number, mğ‘šm, of the most recently-computed pairs {si,yi}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\{s_{i},y_{i}\} where mâ‰ªnmuch-less-thanğ‘šğ‘›m\ll n. (Typically, mâˆˆ[3,7]ğ‘š37m\in[3,7] (see, e.g.,Â [5]).) Together with an intial matrix B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} that depends on kğ‘˜k, these pairs are used to compute Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k}. For notational simplicity, we drop the dependence of the initial matrix on kğ‘˜k and simply denote it as B0subscriptğµ0B_{0}. This limitation on the number of stored pairs allows for a practical implementation of the BFGS method for large-scale optimization.

There are several desirable properties for picking the initial matrix B0subscriptğµ0B_{0}. First, in order for the sequence {Bk}subscriptğµğ‘˜\{B_{k}\} generated by (1) to be symmetric and positive definite, it is necessary that B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is symmetric and positive definite. Second, it is desirable for B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} to be easily invertible so that solving linear systems with any matrix in the sequence is computable using the so-called â€œtwo-loop recursionâ€Â [5] or other recursive formulas for Bkâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜1B_{k}^{-1} (for an overview of other available methods seeÂ [9]). For these reasons, B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is often chosen to be a scalar multiple of the identity matrix, i.e.,

B0=Î³kâ€‹I,withÎ³k>0.formulae-sequencesubscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ¼withsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜0B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I,\quad\text{with}\quad\gamma_{k}>0. (3)

For BFGS matrices, the conventional choice for the initialization parameter Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} is

Î³k=ykTâ€‹ykskTâ€‹yk,subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜\gamma_{k}=\frac{y^{T}_{k}y_{k}}{s^{T}_{k}y_{k}}, (4)

which can be viewed as a spectral estimate for âˆ‡2fâ€‹(xk)superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\nabla^{2}f(x_{k})Â [13]. (This choice was originally proposed inÂ [14] using a derivation based on optimal conditioning.) It is worth noting that this choice of Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} can also be derived as the minimizer of the scalar minimization problem

Î³k=Â argminÂ ğ›¾â€‹â€–B0âˆ’1â€‹ykâˆ’skâ€–22,subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ›¾Â argminÂ subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğµ10subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜22\gamma_{k}=\underset{\gamma}{\text{ argmin }}\left\|B^{-1}_{0}y_{k}-s_{k}\right\|^{2}_{2}, (5)

where B0âˆ’1=Î³âˆ’1â€‹Isubscriptsuperscriptğµ10superscriptğ›¾1ğ¼B^{-1}_{0}=\gamma^{-1}I. For numerical studies on this choice of initialization, see, e.g., the references listed withinÂ [4].


In this paper, we consider a specific dense initialization in lieu of the usual diagonal initialization. The aforementioned separation of â„œnsuperscriptğ‘›\Re^{n} into two orthogonal subspaces allows for different initialization parameters to be used to estimate the curvature of the underlying function in these subspaces. In one space (the space spanned by the most recent updates {si,yi}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\{s_{i},y_{i}\} with kâˆ’mâ‰¤iâ‰¤kâˆ’1ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘˜1k-m\leq i\leq k-1), estimates of the curvature of the underlying function are available, and thus, one initialization parameter can be set using this information. However, in its orthogonal complement, curvature information is not available. Therefore, if the component of the trial step in the orthogonal subspace is (relatively) too large, the predictive quality of the whole trial step is expected to deteriorate. As a result, the trust-region radius might be reduced, despite the fact that the predictive quality of the component in the aforementioned small subspace may be sufficiently good. Separating the whole space into these two subspaces allows users to treat each subspace differently. An alternative view of this initialization is that it makes use of two spectral estimates of âˆ‡2fâ€‹(xk)superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}). Finally, the proposed initialization also allows for efficiently solving and computing products with the resulting quasi-Newton matrices.

The paper is organized in five sections. In Section 2, we review properties of L-BFGS matrices arising from their special recursive structure as well as overview the shape-changing trust-region method to be used in this paper. In Section 3, we present the proposed trust-region method that uses a shape-changing norm together with a dense initialization matrix. While this dense initialization is presented in one specific context, it can be used in combination with any quasi-Newton update that admits a so-called compact representation. Numerical experiments comparing this method with other combinations of initializations and L-BFGS methods are reported in Section 4, and concluding remarks are found in Section 5.

2. Background

In this section, we overview the compact formulation for L-BFGS matrices and how to efficiently compute a partial eigendecomposition. Finally, we review the shape-changing trust-region method considered in this paper.

2.1. The compact representation

The special structure of the recursion formula for L-BFGS matrices admits a so-called compact representationÂ [5], which is overviewed in this section.

2.3. A shape-changing L-BFGS trust-region method

Generally speaking, at the kğ‘˜kth step of a trust-region method, a search direction is computed by approximately solving the trust-region subproblem

pâˆ—=Â argminÂ â€–pâ€–â‰¤Î”kâ€‹Qâ€‹(p)â€‹=â–³gkTâ€‹p+12â€‹pTâ€‹Bkâ€‹p,superscriptğ‘normğ‘subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜Â argminÂ ğ‘„ğ‘superscriptâ–³subscriptsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘12superscriptğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘p^{*}=\underset{\left\|p\right\|\leq{\Delta_{k}}}{\text{ argmin }}Q(p)\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,g^{T}_{k}p+\frac{1}{2}p^{T}B_{k}p, (13)

where gkâ€‹=â–³âˆ‡fâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptâ–³âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜g_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\nabla f(x_{k}), Bkâ‰ˆâˆ‡2fâ€‹(xk)subscriptğµğ‘˜superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜B_{k}\approx\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}), and Î”k>0subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜0\Delta_{k}>0 is the trust-region radius. When second derivatives are unavailable or computationally too expensive to compute, approximations using gradient information may be preferred. Not only do quasi-Newton matrices use only gradient and function information, but in the large-scale case, these Hessian approximations are never stored; instead, a recursive formula or methods that avoid explicitly forming Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} may be used to compute matrix-vector products with the approximate Hessians or their inversesÂ [5, 8, 9, 12].

Consider the trust-region subproblem defined by the shape-changing infinity norm:

where

The overall cost of computing the solution to (14) is comparable to that of using the Euclidean norm (seeÂ [3]). The main advantage of using the shape-changing norm (15) is that the solution pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*} in (23) has a closed-form expression.

3. The Proposed Method

In this section, we present a new dense initialization and demonstrate how it is naturally well-suited for trust-region methods defined by the shape-changing infinity norm. Finally, we present a full trust-region algorithm that uses the dense initialization, consider its computational cost, and prove global convergence.

3.1. Dense initial matrix B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0}

In this section, we propose a new dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods. Importantly, in order to retain the efficiency of quasi-Newton methods the dense initialization matrix and subsequently updated quasi-Newton matrices are never explicitly formed. This initialization can be used with any quasi-Newton update for which there is a compact representation; however, for simplicity, we continue to refer to the BFGS update throughout this section. For notational purposes, we use the initial matrix B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} to represent the usual initialization and B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} to denote the proposed dense initialization. Similarly, {Bk}subscriptğµğ‘˜\{B_{k}\} and {B^k}subscript^ğµğ‘˜\{\widehat{B}_{k}\} will be used to denote the sequences of matrices obtained using the initializations B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} and B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0}, respectively.

Our goal in choosing an alternative initialization is four-fold: (i) to be able to treat subspaces differently depending on whether curvature information is available or not, (ii) to preserve properties of symmetry and positive-definiteness, (iii) to be able to efficiently compute products with the resulting quasi-Newton matrices, and (iv) to be able to efficiently solve linear systems involving the resulting quasi-Newton matrices. The initialization proposed in this paper leans upon two different parameter choices that can be viewed as an estimate of the curvature of âˆ‡2fâ€‹(xk)superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}) in two subspaces: one spanned by the columns of Pâˆ¥subscriptğ‘ƒparallel-toP_{\parallel} and another spanned by the columns of PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp}.

The usual initialization for a BFGS matrix Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} is B0=Î³kâ€‹Isubscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ¼B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I, where Î³k>0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜0\gamma_{k}>0. Note that this initialization is equivalent to

In contrast, for a given Î³k,Î³kâŸ‚âˆˆâ„œsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma_{k},\gamma^{\perp}_{k}\in\Re, consider the following symmetric, and in general, dense initialization matrix:

Corollary 1.

Proof.

The corollary follows immediately by comparing (10) with (25). â–¡â–¡\square âˆ

The results of TheoremÂ 1 and CorollaryÂ 1 may seem surprising at first since every term in the compact representation ((6) and (7)) depends on the initialization; moreover, B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} is, generally speaking, a dense matrix while B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is a diagonal matrix. However, viewed from the perspective of (24), the parameter Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} only plays a role in scaling the subspace spanned by the columns of PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp}.

The initialization B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} allows for two separate curvature approximations for the BFGS matrix: one in the space spanned by columns of Pâˆ¥subscriptğ‘ƒparallel-toP_{\parallel} and another in the space spanned by the columns of PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp}. In the next subsection, we show that this initialization is naturally well-suited for solving trust-region subproblems defined by the shape-changing infinity norm.

3.2. The trust-region subproblem

Here we will show that the use of B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} provides the same subproblem separability as B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} does in the case of the shape-changing infinity norm.

For B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} given by (24), consider the objective function of the trust-region subproblem (14) resulting from the change of variables (16):

3.3. Determining the parameter Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k}

The values Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} and Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} can be updated at each iteration. Since we have little information about the underlying function fğ‘“f in the subspace spanned by the columns of PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp}, it is reasonable to make conservative (i.e., large) choices for Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k}. Note that in the case that Î³kâŸ‚>0â€‹Â andÂ â€‹â€–gâŸ‚â€–2â‰¤Î”kâ€‹|Î³kâŸ‚|subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜0Â andÂ subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”perpendicular-to2subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k}>0\text{ and }\left\|g_{\perp}\right\|_{2}\leq\Delta_{k}|\gamma^{\perp}_{k}|, the parameter Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} scales the solution vâŸ‚âˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘£perpendicular-tov_{\perp}^{*} (see 31); thus, large values of Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} will reduce these step lengths in the space spanned by PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp}. Since the space PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp} does not explicitly use information produced by past iterations, it seems desirable to choose Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} to be large. However, the larger that Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} is chosen, the closer vâŸ‚âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£perpendicular-tov^{*}_{\perp} will be to the zero vector. Also note that if Î³kâŸ‚<0subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜0\gamma^{\perp}_{k}<0 then the solution to the subproblem (29) will always lie on the boundary, and thus, the actual value of Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} becomes irrelevant. Moreover, for values Î³kâŸ‚<0subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜0\gamma^{\perp}_{k}<0, B^ksubscript^ğµğ‘˜\widehat{B}_{k} is not guaranteed to be positive definite. For these reasons, we suggest sufficiently large and positive values for Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} related to the curvature information gathered in Î³1,â€¦,Î³ksubscriptğ›¾1â€¦subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{1},\ldots,\gamma_{k}. Specific choices for Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} are presented in the numerical results section.

The norm equivalence for the shape-changing infinity norm studied inÂ [3] guarantees that (35) implies that the inequality â€–puâˆ—â€–P,âˆâ‰¤Î”ksubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ƒsubscriptÎ”ğ‘˜\|p_{u}^{*}\|_{P,\infty}\leq\Delta_{k} is satisfied; in this case, puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} is the exact solution of the trust-region subproblem defined by the shape-changing infinity norm.

If (35) holds, the algorithm computes puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} for generating the trial point xk+puâˆ—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢x_{k}+p_{u}^{*}. It can be easily seen that the cost of computing puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} is 4â€‹mâ€‹n4ğ‘šğ‘›4mn operations, i.e. it is the same as for computing search direction in the line search L-BFGS algorithm [6].

On the other hand, if (35) does not hold, then for producing a trial point, the partial eigendecomposition is computed, and the trust-region subproblem is decoupled and solved exactly as described in Section 3.2.

3.5. The algorithm and its properties

In AlgorithmÂ 1, we present a basic trust-region method that uses the proposed dense initialization. In this setting, we consider the computational cost of the proposed method, and we prove global convergence of the overall trust-region method. Since Pğ‘ƒP may change every iteration, the corresponding norm âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥P,âˆ\|\cdot\|_{P,\infty} may change each iteration. Note that initially there are no stored quasi-Newton pairs {sj,yj}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—\{s_{j},y_{j}\}. In this case, we assume PâŸ‚=Insubscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-tosubscriptğ¼ğ‘›P_{\perp}=I_{n} and Pâˆ¥subscriptğ‘ƒparallel-toP_{\parallel} does not exist, i.e., B^0=Î³0âŸ‚â€‹Isubscript^ğµ0superscriptsubscriptğ›¾0perpendicular-toğ¼\hat{B}_{0}=\gamma_{0}^{\perp}I.

The only difference between AlgorithmÂ 1 and the LMTR algorithm inÂ [3] is the initialization matrix. Computationally speaking, the use of a dense initialization in lieu of a diagonal initialization plays out only in the computation of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*} by (22). However, there is no computational cost difference: The cost of computing the value for Î²ğ›½\beta using (31) in AlgorithmÂ 1 instead of (21) in the LMTR algorithm is the same. Thus, the dominant cost per iteration for both AlgorithmÂ 1 and the LMTR algorithm is 4â€‹mâ€‹n4ğ‘šğ‘›4mn operations (seeÂ [3] for details). Note that this is the same cost-per-iteration as the line search L-BFGS algorithmÂ [5].

In the next result, we provide a global convergence result for AlgorithmÂ 1. This result is based on the convergence analysis presented inÂ [3].

Substituting in for the definitions of yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k} and sksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s_{k} yields that

Î³kâ‰¤â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xk+1)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(xk)â€–c3â€‹â€–xk+1âˆ’xkâ€–,subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘3normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\gamma_{k}\leq\frac{\|\nabla f(x_{k+1})-\nabla f(x_{k})\|}{c_{3}\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|},

implying that (38) holds. Thus, AlgorithmÂ 1 converges for these choices for Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}.

4. Numerical Experiments

We performed numerical experiments using a Dell Precision T1700 machine with an Intel i5-4590 CPU at 3.303.303.30GHz X4 and 8GB RAM using MATLAB 2014a. The test set consisted of 65 large-scale (1000â‰¤nâ‰¤100001000ğ‘›100001000\leq n\leq 10000) CUTEstÂ [10] test problems, made up of all the test problems inÂ [3] plus an additional three (FMINSURF, PENALTY2, and TESTQUADÂ [10]) since at least one of the methods in the experiments detailed below converged on one of these three problems. The same trust-region method and default parameters as inÂ [3, Algorithm 1] were used for the outer iteration. At most five quasi-Newton pairs {sk,yk}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜\{s_{k},y_{k}\} were stored, i.e., m=5ğ‘š5m=5. The relative stopping criterion was

â€–gkâ€–2â‰¤Ïµâ€‹maxâ¡(1,â€–xkâ€–2),subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜2italic-Ïµ1subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2\left\|g_{k}\right\|_{2}\leq\epsilon\max\left(1,\left\|x_{k}\right\|_{2}\right),

with Ïµ=10âˆ’10italic-Ïµsuperscript1010\epsilon=10^{-10}. The initial step, p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}, was determined by a backtracking line-search along the normalized steepest descent direction. To compute the partial eigendecomposition of Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k}, we used the QR factorization instead of the SVD because the QR version outperformed the SVD version in numerical experiments not presented here. The rank of Î¨ksubscriptÎ¨ğ‘˜\Psi_{k} was estimated by the number of positive diagonal elements in the diagonal matrix of the LDLTsuperscriptLDLT\text{LDL}^{\text{T}} decomposition (or eigendecomposition of Î¨kTâ€‹Î¨ksubscriptsuperscriptÎ¨ğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscriptÎ¨ğ‘˜\Psi^{T}_{k}\Psi_{k}) that are larger than the threshold Ïµr=(10âˆ’7)2subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsuperscript1072\epsilon_{r}=(10^{-7})^{2}. (Note that the columns of Î¨ksubscriptÎ¨ğ‘˜\Psi_{k} are normalized.). We used the value c3=10âˆ’8subscriptğ‘3superscript108c_{3}=10^{-8} in (39) for testing whether to accept a new quasi-Newton pair.

We provide performance profiles (see [7]) for the number of iterations (iter) where the trust-region step is accepted and the average time (time) for each solver on the test set of problems. The performance metric, ÏğœŒ\rho, for the 65 problems is defined by

Ïsâ€‹(Ï„)=cardâ€‹{p:Ï€p,sâ‰¤Ï„}65andÏ€p,s=tp,sÂ minÂ â€‹tp,i1â‰¤iâ‰¤S,formulae-sequencesubscriptğœŒğ‘ ğœcardconditional-setğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘ ğœ65andsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ 1ğ‘–ğ‘†Â minÂ subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘–\rho_{s}(\tau)=\frac{\text{card}\left\{p:\pi_{p,s}\leq\tau\right\}}{65}\quad\text{and}\quad\pi_{p,s}=\frac{t_{p,s}}{\underset{1\leq i\leq S}{\text{ min }t_{p,i}}},

where tp,ssubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ t_{p,s} is the â€œoutputâ€ (i.e., time or iterations) of â€œsolverâ€ sğ‘ s on problem pğ‘p. Here Sğ‘†S denotes the total number of solvers for a given comparison. This metric measures the proportion of how close a given solver is to the best result. We observe as in [3] that the first runs significantly differ in time from the remaining runs, and thus, we ran each algorithm ten times on each problem, reporting the average of the final eight runs.


In this section, we present the following six types of experiments involving LMTR:

  1. (1)

    A comparison of results for different values of Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(c,Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-toğ‘ğœ†\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda).

  2. (2)

    Two versions of computing the full quasi-Newton trial step are compared. One version uses the dense initialization to compute puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} as described in Section 3.4 (see (33)); the other uses the conventional initialization, i.e., puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} is computed as puâˆ—=Bkâˆ’1â€‹gksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜p_{u}^{*}=B_{k}^{-1}g_{k}. When the full quasi-Newton trial step is not accepted in any of the versions, the dense initialization is used for computing trial step by explicitly solving the trust-region subproblem (Section 3.2).

  3. (3)

    A comparison of LMTR together with a dense initialization and the line search L-BFGS method with the conventional initialization.

  4. (4)

    A comparison of LMTR with a dense initialization and L-BFGS-TRÂ [3], which computes a scaled quasi-Newton direction that lies inside a trust region. This method can be viewed as a hybrid line search and trust-region algorithm.

  5. (5)

    A comparison of the dense and conventional initializations.

In the experiments below, the dense initial matrix B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} corresponding to Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(c,Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-toğ‘ğœ†\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda) given in (41) will be denoted by

B^0â€‹(c,Î»)â€‹=â–³Î³kâ€‹Pâˆ¥â€‹Pâˆ¥T+Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(c,Î»)â€‹PâŸ‚â€‹PâŸ‚T.subscript^ğµ0ğ‘ğœ†superscriptâ–³subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒparallel-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒparallel-toğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-toğ‘ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toğ‘‡\widehat{B}_{0}(c,\lambda)\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\gamma_{k}P_{\parallel}P_{\parallel}^{T}+\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda)P_{\perp}P_{\perp}^{T}.

Using this notation, the conventional initialization B0â€‹(Î³k)subscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜B_{0}(\gamma_{k}) can be written as B^0â€‹(1,0)subscript^ğµ010\widehat{B}_{0}(1,0).

Experiment 1. In this experiment, we consider various scalings of a proposed Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} using LMTR. As argued in Section 3.3, it is reasonable to choose Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} to be large and positive; in particular, Î³kâŸ‚â‰¥Î³ksuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-tosubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k}^{\perp}\geq\gamma_{k}. Thus, we consider the parametrized family of choices Î³kâŸ‚â€‹=â–³Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(c,Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-tosuperscriptâ–³superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-toğ‘ğœ†\gamma_{k}^{\perp}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda) given in (41). These choices correspond to conservative strategies for computing steps in the space spanned by PâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒperpendicular-toP_{\perp} (see the discussion in Section 3.3). Moreover, these can also be viewed as conservative strategies since the trial step computed using B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} will always be larger in Euclidean norm than the trial step computed using B^0subscript^ğµ0\widehat{B}_{0} using (41). To see this, note that in the parallel subspace the solutions will be identical using both initializations since the solution vâˆ¥âˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘£parallel-tov_{\parallel}^{*} does not depend on Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} (see (19)); in contrast, in the orthogonal subspace, â€–vâŸ‚âˆ—â€–normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£perpendicular-to\|v_{\perp}^{*}\| inversely depends on Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} (see (30) and (31)).

We report results using different values of cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda for Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(c,Î»)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜ğ‘ğœ†\gamma^{\perp}_{k}(c,\lambda) on two sets of tests. On the first set of tests, the dense initialization was used for the entire LMTR algoirthm. However, for the second set of tests, the dense initialization was not used for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*}; that is, LMTR was run using Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} (initialized with B0=Î³kâ€‹Isubscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ¼B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} is given in (4)) for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer puâˆ—=âˆ’Bkâˆ’1â€‹gksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜p_{u}^{*}=-B_{k}^{-1}g_{k}. However, if the unconstrained minimizer was not taken to be the approximate solution of the subproblem, B^ksubscript^ğµğ‘˜\widehat{B}_{k} with the dense initialization was used for computing the constrained minimizer with respect to the shape-changing norm (see line 8 in Algorithm 1) with Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} defined as in (41). The values of cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda chosen for Experiment 1 are found in Table 1. (See SectionÂ 3.4 for details on the LMTR algorithm.)

FigureÂ 1 displays the performance profiles using the chosen values of cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda to define Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} in the case when the dense initialization was used for both the computation of the unconstrained minimizer puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} (line 10 of Algorithm 1) as well as for the constrained minimizer with respect to the shape-changing norm (line 8 of Algorithm 1), which is denoted in the legend of plots in FigureÂ 1 by the use of an asterisk (âˆ—)(*). The results of FigureÂ 1 suggest the choice of c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=12ğœ†12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} outperform the other chosen combinations for cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda. In experiments not reported here, larger values of cğ‘c did not appear to improve performance; for c<1ğ‘1c<1, performance deteriorated. Moreover, other choices for Î»ğœ†\lambda, such as Î»=34ğœ†34\lambda=\frac{3}{4}, did not improve results beyond the choice of Î»=12ğœ†12\lambda=\frac{1}{2}.

FigureÂ 2 reports the performance profiles for using the chosen values of cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda to define Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} in the case when the dense initialization was only used for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1) â€“denoted in the legend of plots in FigureÂ 2 by the absence of an asterisk (âˆ—)(*). In this test, the combination of c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 as well as c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=12ğœ†12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} appear to slightly outperform the other two choices for Î³kâŸ‚subscriptsuperscriptğ›¾perpendicular-toğ‘˜\gamma^{\perp}_{k} in terms of both then number of iterations and the total computational time. Based on the results in FigureÂ 2, we do not see a reason to prefer either combination c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 or c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=12ğœ†12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} over the other.

Note that for the CUTEst problems, the full quasi-Newton trial step is accepted as the solution to the subproblem on the overwhelming majority of problems. Thus, if the scaling Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} is used only when the full trial step is rejected, it has less of an affect on the overall performance of the algorithm; i.e., the algorithm is less sensitive to the choice of Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}. For this reason, it is not surprising that the performance profiles in FigureÂ 2 for the different values of Î³kâŸ‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} are more indistinguishable than those in FigureÂ 1.

Finally, similar to the results in the case when the dense initialization was used for the entire algorithm (FigureÂ 1), other values of cğ‘c and Î»ğœ†\lambda did not significantly improve the performance provided by c=1ğ‘1c=1 and Î»=12ğœ†12\lambda=\frac{1}{2}.


Experiment 2. This experiment was designed to test whether it is advantageous to use the dense initialization for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm or just for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1). For any given trust-region subproblem, using the dense initialization for computing the unconstrained minimizer is computationally more expensive than using a diagonal initialization; however, it is possible that extra computational time associated with using the dense initialization for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm may yield a more overall efficient solver. For these tests, we compare the top performer in the case when the dense initialization is used for all aspects of LMTR, i.e., (Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,12))superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to112(\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2})), to one of the top performers in the case when the dense initialization is used only for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1), i.e., (Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,1))superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to11(\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,1)).

The performance profiles comparing the results of this experiment are presented in Figure 3. These results suggest that using the dense initialization with Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,12)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm is more efficient than using dense initializations only for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1). In other words, even though using dense initial matrices for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer imposes an additional computational burden, it generates steps that expedite the convergence of the overall trust-region method.


Experiment 3. In this experiment, we compare the performance of the dense initialization Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,0.5)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to10.5\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,0.5) to that of the line-search L-BFGS algorithm. For this comparison, we used the publicly-available MATLAB wrapperÂ [1] for the FORTRAN L-BFGS-B code developed by Nocedal et al.Â [15]. The initialization for L-BFGS-B is B0=Î³kâ€‹Isubscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ¼B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} is given by (4). To make the stopping criterion equivalent to that of L-BFGS-B, we modified the stopping criterion of our solver toÂ [15]:

â€–gkâ€–âˆâ‰¤Ïµ.subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜italic-Ïµ\left\|g_{k}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\epsilon.

The dense initialization was used for all aspects of LMTR.

The performance profiles for this experiment is given in FigureÂ 4. On this test set, the dense initialization outperforms L-BFGS-B in terms of both the number of iterations and the total computational time.


Experiment 4. In this experiment, we compare LMTR with a dense initialization to L-BFGS-TRÂ [3], which computes an L-BFGS trial step whose length is bounded by a trust-region radius. This method can be viewed as a hybrid L-BFGS line search and trust-region algorithm because it uses a standard trust-region framework (as LMTR) but computes a trial point by minimizing the quadratic model in the trust region along the L-BFGS direction. InÂ [3], it was determined that this algorithm outperforms two other versions of L-BFGS that use a Wolfe line search. (For further details, seeÂ [3].)

FigureÂ 5 displays the performance profiles associated with this experiment on the entire set of test problems. For this experiment, the dense initialization with Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,12)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) was used in all aspects of the LMTR algorithm. In terms of total number of iterations, LMTR with the dense initialization outperformed L-BFGS-TR; however, L-BFGS-TR appears to have outperformed LMTR with the dense initialization in computational time.

FigureÂ 5 (left) indicates that the quality of the trial points produced by solving the trust-region subproblem exactly using LMTR with the dense initialization is generally better than in the case of the line search applied to the L-BFGS direction. However, FigureÂ 5 (right) shows that LMTR with the dense initialization requires more computational effort than L-BFGS-TR. For the CUTEst set of test problems, L-BFGS-TR does not need to perform a line search for the majority of iterations; that is, the full quasi-Newton trial step is accepted in a majority of the iterations. Therefore, we also compared the two algorithms on a subset of the most difficult test problemsâ€“namely, those for which an active line search is needed to be performed by L-BFGS-TR. To this end, we select, as inÂ [3], those of the CUTEst problems in which the full L-BFGS (i.e., the step size of one) was rejected in at least 30% of the iterations. The number of problems in this subset is 14. The performance profiles associated with this reduced test set are in FigureÂ 6. On this smaller test set, LMTR outperforms L-BFGS-TR both in terms of total number of iterations and computational time.

Finally, FiguresÂ 5 andÂ 6 suggest that when function and gradient evaluations are expensive (e.g., simulation-based applications), LMTR together with the dense initialization is expected to be more efficient than L-BFGS-TR since both on both test sets LMTR with the dense initialization requires fewer overall iterations. Moreover, FigureÂ 6 suggests that on problems where the L-BFGS search direction often does not provide sufficient decrease of the objective function, LMTR with the dense initialization is expected to perform better.


Experiment 5. In this experiment, we compare the results of LMTR using the dense initialization to that of LMTR using the conventional diagonal initialization B0=Î³kâ€‹Isubscriptğµ0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğ¼B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} is given by (3). The dense initialization selected was chosen to be the top performer from Experiment 2 (i.e., Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,12)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2})).

From FigureÂ 7, the dense initialization with Î³kâŸ‚â€‹(1,12)superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜perpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) outperforms the conventional initialization for LMTR in terms of iteration count; however, it is unclear whether the algorithm benefits from the dense initialization in terms of computational time. The reason for this is that the dense initialization is being used for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm; in particular, it is being used to compute the full quasi-Newton step puâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p_{u}^{*} (see the discussion in Experiment 1), which is typically accepted most iterations on the CUTEst test set. Therefore, as in Experiment 5, we compared LMTR with the dense initialization and the conventional initialization on the subset of 14 problems in which the unconstrained minimizer is rejected at least 30% of the iterations. The performance profiles associated with this reduced set of problems are found in FigureÂ 8. The results from this experiment clearly indicate that on these more difficult problems the dense initialization outperforms the conventional initialization in both iteration count and computational time.

5. Conclusion

In this paper, we presented a dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods to solve unconstrained optimization problems. This initialization makes use of two curvature estimates for the underlying function in two complementary subspaces. Importantly, this initialization neither introduces additional computational cost nor increases storage requirements; moreover, it maintains theoretical convergence properties of quasi-Newton methods. It should also be noted that this initialization still makes it possible to efficiently compute products and perform solves with the sequence of quasi-Newton matrices.

The dense initialization is especially well-suited for use in the shape-changing infinity-norm L-BFGS trust-region method. Numerical results on the outperforms both the standard L-BFGS line search method as well as the same shape-changing trust-region method with the conventional initialization. Use of this initialization is possible with any quasi-Newton method for which the update has a compact representation. While this initialization has broad applications for quasi-Newton line search and trust-region methods, its use makes most sense from a computational point of view when the quasi-Newton method already computes the compact formulation and partial eigendecomposition; if this is not the case, using the dense initialization will result in additional computational expense that must be weighed against its benefits.
